issue.title: release: Checking binary compatibility
issue.body:
When looking into binary compatibility (see #1055, #964), I found this nice website which describes best practices and open source tools for checking binary compatibility: https://abi-laboratory.pro This may be something to look into *after* the first release (but maybe before the second release).

See for example [the report for Botan](https://abi-laboratory.pro/index.php?view=timeline&l=botan), [which by the way doesn't provide binary compatibility across versions at all](https://botan.randombit.net/handbook/abi.html).

milestone.title: stable release (1.0.0-rc.1)
milestone.description:
Motivation: libsecp is already widely used today, but often in a terribly outdated version. It's likely that a release process would help with that. Moreover, it simplifies using libsecp which may prevent developers from using less well tested alternatives. Lastly, without releases it's difficult to update the library in an organized fashion and communicate these updates.

Release Goals:

- Stabilize API and documentation for functionality that exist today.
- Fix a few known bugs.
- Make ECDH non-experimental.

This milestone can be discussed in issue https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/issues/286.

events.body:
FWIW, here is what I've got for the recent releases:
- [API compatibility report for the libsecp256k1.so object between 0.2.0 and 0.3.0 versions on x86_64](https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/hebasto/artefacts/blob/master/libsecp256k1%20ABI%20compatibility/compat_reports/libsecp256k1/0.2.0_to_0.3.0/compat_report.html)
- [API compatibility report for the libsecp256k1.so object between 0.3.0 and 0.3.1 versions on x86_64](https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/hebasto/artefacts/blob/master/libsecp256k1%20ABI%20compatibility/compat_reports/libsecp256k1/0.3.0_to_0.3.1/compat_report.html)

**UPD.**
For 0.3.0 --> 0.3.1:
- "The parameter `tweak32` became passed in `rbp` register instead of `r13`." in `secp256k1_ec_seckey_tweak_add ()` is caused by the 4a496a36fb07d6cc8c99e591994f4ce0c3b1174c commit from #1257.
- "The parameter `seckey` became passed in `rbx` register instead of `rbp`." in `secp256k1_ec_seckey_tweak_mul()` can be avoided if compiled with `-fno-omit-frame-pointer`.
@hebasto I don't understand how that commit can have any effect on the public ABI.

> @hebasto I don't understand how that commit can have any effect on the public ABI.

Neither do I. That was reported by the tool. Maybe a false positive report?
In fact, both claimed versions sound incorrect. The third (`tweak32`) argument on x86_64 calling convention should be passed in the `rdx` register.

Interestingly, the dumps generated with gcc 10 don't have any "Reg"(ister) entries in their json file, whereas the dumps generated with gcc 11 list registers for some arguments...  

Maybe open an issue with the tool?

> Interestingly, the dumps generated with gcc 10 don't have any "Reg"(ister) entries in their json file, whereas the dumps generated with gcc 11 list registers for some arguments...
> 
> Maybe open an issue with the tool?

The issue has been solved by forcing DWARF v4.

issue.title: Add ABI checking tool for release process
issue.body:
Closes https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/issues/1136.

An example of using the `check-abi.sh` tool against changes from https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1140:

![image](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/assets/32963518/6761f4f4-c1b5-468e-bd73-d178f60ef931)
